Scheme 1 Fig. 1 XRD patterns of γ-Al2O3 support, the material after DP, and Ni3P/γ-Al2O3. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 (a) TEM images and particle size distribution of Ni3P/γ-Al2O3. (b) High-resolution TEM images of Ni3P/γ-Al2O3. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 XPS spectra of Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 catalyst in (a) Ni 2p and (b) P 2p regions. A bifunctional Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 catalyst with both metal site and Lewis acid site was prepared by an electroless plating method, and applied in hydrogenative ring-rearrangement of furfural to cyclopentanone. The obtained catalyst was characterized by XRD, XPS, XAS, N2 adsorption-desorption, ICP, TEM, CO chemisorption, NH3-TPD and Py-FTIR. The ultrafine Ni3P nanoparticles (∼3.8 nm) were highly dispersed in the catalyst. The exclusive Lewis acidity of Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 was beneficial for the aqueous-phase hydrogenative ring-rearrangement. The effects of DP time, reaction parameters (temperature, H2 pressure, solvent composition, and reaction time) on the catalytic performance were investigated. The yield of cyclopentanone was 74.6% at furfural conversion of 99.9% at 180 °C in 1 h over Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 catalyst using pure water as the solvent. Moreover, the kinetics of hydrogenative ring-rearrangement of furfural catalyzed by Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 was investigated. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 Hydrogenative ring-rearrangement Furfural Cyclopentanone Electroless plating 1 Introduction Cyclopentanone (CPO), a versatile platform compound, is used in the synthesis of rubber chemicals, fungicides, pharmaceuticals, flavors, fragrance chemicals, and polyamides [1,2]. Currently, CPO is produced from 1,6-hexanediol, adipic esters and cyclopentene by the petro-chemical routes, which require harsh reaction conditions, multi-step processes and expensive raw materials [3,4]. In recent decades, a novel route has been developed to produce CPO from the biomass-based furfural (FAL) by aqueous-phase hydrogenative ring-arrangement [5–10]. Furfural, one of the top 30 biomass-derived platform compounds proposed by DOE, is mainly produced by hydrolysis and dehydration of xylan, which exists in large quantities in hemicellulose (25–35% of lignocellulosic biomass) [8,11,12]. The transformation of FAL to CPO involves hydrogenation and ring-arrangement (Piancatelli rearrangement), thus requiring both metal site and Lewis acid site [2]. Precious metals (Pd, Ru, Pt, Au, Ir) are frequently-used catalysts, and Pd-based catalysts exhibited the highest performance [1,13-16]. It is desirable to use non-precious metals which exhibit high hydrogenation performance at mild conditions. Since water played a crucial role in the Piancatelli rearrangement [2], the hydrogenative ring-rearrangement of furfural to cyclopentanone was carried out in an aqueous phase. In the previous study, we found that Ni3P performed comparable activity to Pd and good stability in the hydrogenation of phenol at low temperature in aqueous phase [17]. Nevertheless, the acid-catalyzed dehydration activity of unsupported Ni3P was insufficient. An introduction of solid acid materials will help to construct a bifunctional catalyst. The Lewis acidity was beneficial to promote the ring-rearrangement of FAL, increasing the selectivity to CPO, whereas the Brønsted acidity facilitated the polymerization of FAL and furfuryl alcohol (FOL, the hydrogenated product), producing the by-products and decreasing the carbon balance [1,5]. On account of the exclusive Lewis acidity, excellent mechanical strength and low price, γ-Al2O3 is widely applied to the industrial hydrotreating process as a support or a catalyst [16,18-21]. Hence, the γ-Al2O3 supported Ni3P (Ni3P/γ-Al2O3) is a promising catalyst for the transformation of FAL to CPO. Traditionally, the H2 temperature-programmed-reduction (H2-TPR) method was adopted in preparing supported nickel phosphide catalyst [22,23]. However, the high-temperature calcination and reduction in H2-TPR might lead to the inhomogeneous distribution and aggregation for the catalysts. On account of the strong interaction between Al and P species at high temperatures, it is hard to prepare γ-Al2O3 supported nickel phosphide catalyst in H2-TPR [24,25]. In our previous study, an electroless plating (EP) method was applied to prepare the Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 catalyst [20]. In the EP process, the catalyst was prepared at low temperature (≤ 400 °C) [26,27], which was not only beneficial to supress the Al-P interaction, but also to maintain the dispersion of the catalytic active sites. Prior to EP, a highly-dispersed Ni-containing precursor was prepared by a homogeneous deposition-precipitation (DP) method, which is widely used for preparing the highly-dispersed metal catalysts [28–30]. Herein, a procedure combining the DP and EP methods was proposed to prepare the highly-dispersed Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. The catalytic performance of the prepared Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 was investigated using FAL in water as the substrates. The influence of reaction conditions (including temperature, pressure, time and solvent) on the catalytic performance of Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 in FAL hydrogenative ring-rearrangement were investigated. In addition, the rate constants and activation energy of FAL hydrogenative ring-rearrangement over Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 were obtained. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials The chemical reagents were of analytical grade and used without further purification. Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, CO(NH2)2, NaH2PO2, CH3COONa, CH3COOH, and HNO3 were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). Furfural, furfuryl alcohol and cyclopentanone were supplied by Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co. (Shanghai, China). 2.2 Preparation and pretreatment of the supports Al-MCM-41 was prepared following the procedure reported previously [31]. The general procedure was as follows: 8.25 g of Na2SiO3·5H2O, 2.20 g of CTAB, and 0.13 g of aluminum isopropoxide were dissolved in 15 mL, 35 mL, and 20 mL of deionized water to form Solution A, B, and C, respectively. After sequential addition of Solution B and C into A, the pH was adjusted to 11 by adding 6 M H2SO4 to obtain Suspension D. After vigorously stirring at ambient temperature for 2 h, the pH was slightly adjusted. The mixture was placed into a static stainless steel autoclave, and kept at 120 °C for 48 h. After cooling to ambient temperature, the resulting solid material was recovered by filtration, washed with water, dried at 60 °C for 12 h, and calcined at 550 °C for 6 h. Al-SBA-15 was prepared following the procedure reported previously [32]. 8 g of copolymer triblock Pluronic 123 (P123, surfactant) was dissolved in 300 mL HCl solution (pH = 1.5). Then, 18 mL of TEOS was added dropwise, followed by the addition of the appropriate amount of aluminum isopropoxide to achieve a Si/Al molar ratio of 20. After vigorously stirring at 50 °C for 24 h, the mixture was placed into a static stainless steel autoclave, and kept at 80 °C for 24 h. Finally, the sample was recovered by filtration, washed with water, dried at 100 °C for 12 h, and calcined at 600 °C for 8 h to ensure the complete removal of the template. γ-Al2O3 was calcined at 550 °C for 3 h before use. TiO2 (P25) was used without further purification. 2.3 Catalyst preparation The preparation of highly dispersed Ni3P catalysts over various supports by electroless plating (EP) was described in detail in the previous publication [20]. Typically, 2.6 g Ni(NO3)2·6H2O was dissolved in 300 mL deionized water to form Solution A. 2.4 g γ-Al2O3 was dispersed in 240 mL Solution A to form Suspension B, whereas 7.6 g urea and 0.6 mL HNO3 were dissolved in the remaining 60 mL Solution A to obtain Solution C. After heating Suspension B to 70 °C, Solution C was added dropwise to form Suspension D. Afterwards, Suspension D was heated to 90 °C and kept for 4–16 h. The nickel-containing Precursor E was obtained by filtration, washing with deionized water and drying overnight at 110 °C. 9.5 g of NaH2PO2 was dissolved in a 100 mL buffer solution (CH3COOHCH3COONa, pH = 5.5). After heating the solution to 90 °C in an oil bath, the prepared Precursor E was added slowly into the solution. The solid product F was collected by vacuum filtration, washing, and drying at 120 °C for 12 h. The exothermic peak at around 400 °C (Fig. S1) could be related to the crystallization of amorphous Ni-P to Ni3P crystallite [33]. Thus, the product F was subsequently thermally treated at 400 °C for 2 h in a hydrogen flow to obtain Ni3P/γ-Al2O3. 2.4 Catalyst characterization A Rigaku D/Max 2400 diffractometer (λ = 0.15406 nm, 40 kV, 100 mA) was used to collect the X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns. N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms were measured on a Micrometritics Tristar II 3020 at −196 °C to obtain the BET specific surface area (SBET ). The particle size distribution, crystal lattice and elemental mapping images were observed on a transmission electron microscope (TEM) (Tecnai G2 F30, 300 kV). The Ni and P contents were determined by means of inductively coupled plasma (ICP) on an Optima 2000DV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses were carried out on a Multilab2000 X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (Mg-Kα source), using C 1 s peak at 284.6 eV as the reference. Ni K-edge X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) for the catalysts was measured at the BL14W1 beamline of the Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility, in fluorescence mode, using a Lytle detector to collect the data, using Ni foil as the standard. The data were analyzed by using the Demeter software package, normalizing and analyzing the configuration environment by Athena and Artemis software, respectively. CO chemisorption was conducted on a Chembet-3000 analyzer by pulse injection. The temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) was recorded by a Chembet-3000 analyzer. The Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy of adsorbed pyridine (Py-FTIR) was conducted on an operando dual-beam Fourier transform infrared (DB-FTIR) spectrometer from 4000 to 400 cm−1 with an optical resolution of 4 cm−1. 2.5 Catalytic reaction The aqueous-phase hydrogenative ring-rearrangement of furfural was carried out in a 100 mL stainless steel autoclave (equipped with quartz liner, external temperature controller, mechanical stirrer and pressure gage). A reaction mixture of furfural (10.4 mmol), deionized water (20 mL) and catalyst (0.2 g) was added to the autoclave. N2 was purged to flush the reactor, followed by charging H2 to certain pressure (4 MPa) and heated to the reaction temperature with the stirring speed of 750 rpm. After the catalytic reaction, the autoclave was transferred to an ice bath allowing to cool down rapidly to ambient temperature. The liquid products were collected by centrifugation and analyzed by gas chromatography (GC) (Agilent 7890, HP-INNOWax capillary column and flame ionization detector) with dioxane as an internal standard. The FAL conversions, product yield, and selectivity were calculated as follows: (1) C o n v e r s i o n = n F A L , 0 − n F A L n F A L , 0 × 100 % (2) Y i e l d = n p r o d u c t , i n F A L + ∑ n p r o d u c t , i × 100 % (3) S e l e c t i v i t y = n p r o d u c t , i ∑ n p r o d u c t , i × 100 % where n F A L , 0 and n F A L (mol·L − 1) represent the concentration of furfural in the feed and product, respectively, and n p r o d u c t , i (mol·L − 1) is the concentration of product i. The turnover frequency (TOF) was determined by: (4) T O F = n F A L , 0 × x N C O × m c a t a l y s t × t where x, N C O , m c a t a l y s t and t stand for the furfural conversion, CO uptake (μmol·g − 1), catalyst dosage (g) and reaction time (h), respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of support Scheme 1 illustrates the reaction network of FAL hydrogenative ring-rearrangement in water. The transformation of FAL to CPO proceeded in five consecutive steps [6,13]: (1) FAL hydrogenation to FOL, (2) FOL hydrolysis ring-opening to 2-pentene-1,4‑dione (PED), (3) PED intramolecular aldol to 4‑hydroxy-2-cyclopentenone (HCP), (4) HCP dehydration and hydrogenation to 2-CPE, (5) 2-CPE hydrogenation to CPO. Moreover, FOL, PED, and CPO could be further hydrogenated to THFOL, 5-HPO and CPL, respectively. The main products detected in the liquid product were CPO, cyclopentanol (CPL), FOL, tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFOL), and 5‑hydroxy-pentanone (5-HPO) (Fig. S2). Table 1 comparably shows the catalytic performance of the supported Ni3P in aqueous-phase hydrogenative ring-rearrangement of FAL. The TOFs of the catalysts in hydrogenative ring-rearrangement of FAL can be calculated according to the CO uptake and listed in Table 1. It is shown that TOF decreased in the order: Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 > Ni3P/TiO2 > Ni3P/Al-MCM-41 > Ni2P/Al-SBA-15. Among the catalysts, Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 exhibited the highest performance, with CPO selectivity of 81.3% at FAL conversion of 89.1%. The major byproducts were the over-hydrogenated THFOL, 5-HPO and CPL, with the selectivity of 2.0%, 9.5% and 1.6%, respectively. In the Ni3P/Al-MCM-41 catalyzed aqueous-phase hydrogenative ring-rearrangement, the conversion of FAL and selectivity to CPO decreased to 62.2% and 53.9%, respectively. The high content of FOL (selectivity of 22.2%) indicated the insufficient ring-arrangement activity, which might be due to the weak acidity of the Ni3P/Al-MCM-41 catalyst. Over Ni3P/Al-SBA-15 and Ni3P/TiO2, the FAL conversion was 32.3% and 32.0%, respectively, smaller than that over Ni3P/γ-Al2O3. Compared with Ni3P/γ-Al2O3, the carbon balance decreased over the other three catalysts, which might be due to the increased acid strength (Fig. S3). In a word, Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 was the optimal catalyst in the aqueous-phase hydrogenative ring-rearrangement of FAL for further investigation. 3.2 Characterization of Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 catalyst Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the γ-Al2O3 support, the material after DP, and Ni3P/γ-Al2O3. After the stepwise DP, EP, and thermal treatment (TT), the crystal phase of γ-Al2O3 was unchanged. After DP for 16 h, the diffraction peaks characteristic of Ni5Al4O11·18H2O (JCPDS No. 22–0452) were detected. After a sequent EP and TT, the weak diffraction peaks at 2θ = 36.3, 43.7, 46.7, and 50.6 ° were observed in the XRD pattern of Ni3P/γ-Al2O3, attributable to the Ni3P lattice plane of (301), (112), (141), and (222), respectively (JCPDS No. 34–0501). Fig. 2 shows the TEM images, and particle size distribution of Ni3P/γ-Al2O3. Large quantities of Ni3P nanosized particles were uniformly dispersed on the catalyst, with an average particle size of ∼3.8 nm. The lattice fringes were observed in the high-resolution image (Fig. 2b), with lattice space of 0.207, 0.211 and 0.216 nm, corresponding to the (112), (330), and (231) planes of Ni3P, respectively. The lattice fringes ascribing to Ni metal were not observed, indicating the crystal Ni3P was the major phase in the catalyst. When the γ-Al2O3-supported Ni3P was prepared by H2-TPR method, the major crystal phase was metallic Ni, with an average particle size of 11.9 nm [20]. EP was conducted at mild conditions, avoiding the high-temperature-induced P-Al interaction and particle agglomeration. As a result, a highly dispersed Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was prepared by EP. Fig. 3 shows the XPS spectra of Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 in the regions of Ni 2p and P 2p. The Ni 2p XPS spectrum presented six peaks, representing Niδ+ (852.5 eV for 2p3/2, and 870 eV for 2p1/2), and Ni2+ (856.5 eV for 2p3/2, and 874.0 eV for 2p1/2) accompanied by satellite peak (861.9 eV for 2p3/2, and 879.5 eV for 2p1/2) [34]. In the core level of P 2p, two peaks at 129.2 eV (2p3/2) and 130.1 eV (2p1/2) can be assigned to Pδ−, and the other two peaks at 133.1 eV (2p3/2) and 134.0 eV (2p1/2) can be assigned to oxidized P species [35]. The binding energies of Niδ+ and Pδ− are close to those of Ni and P elements, respectively [36]. Exposure to air might generate oxidized Ni and P species [24]. The electronic state of the Ni species in the preparation of Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 by DP-EP was investigated by means of X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) analysis. During the DP-EP process, the nickel aluminum oxide hydrate (Ni5Al4O11·18H2O), and Ni3P were formed consecutively, after the sequent DP and EP, respectively [20]. The X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra of Ni5Al4O11·18H2O and Ni3P/γ-Al2O3, in comparison with Ni foil are shown in Fig. 4 a. The Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 showed a different XANES spectrum from Ni5Al4O11·18H2O, implying the main crystal phase was transformed after the EP. The white line peak of Ni at 8349 eV from Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 indicated the partly oxidation due to the exposure to air, in accordance with the XPS spectrum (Fig. 3a) Fig. 4.b shows the Fourier transform Ni K-edge EXAFS spectra of the materials. The Ni5Al4O11·18H2O showed two peaks at distances of 1.7 and 2.7 Å, corresponding to Ni-O and Ni-O-Ni bond, respectively [37]. As for Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 catalysts, the two peaks at distances of 1.6 and 2.3 Å could be ascribed to Ni-P and Ni-Ni bonds, respectively [38]. In addition, the EXAFS spectra were fitted to determine the local structures of the Ni species (Fig. S3). As seen in Table S1, the Ni-Ni bond distance of Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 (2.65 Å) was longer than that of Ni foil (2.48 Å), due to the incorporation of P species. The NH3-TPD curve of Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 is shown in Fig. 5 a. The desorption peaks at 150–250 °C and 350–400 °C were ascribed to the weak and strong acid sites, respectively. Moreover, the acid amount of weak acid was far larger than that of strong acid, indicating that the major acid was weak acid. Wu et al. found that the peak maximun for Ni2P/Al2O3 was at about 208 °C, indicative of weak acid as the main acid [39]. The Py-FTIR spectra were measured at 150, 300, and 450 °C separately to distinguish the acid type (Fig. 5b). The peak at 1444 cm−1 was assigned to Lewis acid, while that at 1491 cm−1 was ascribed to both Lewis acid and Brønsted acid. The peak assigned to Brønsted acid (around 1540 cm−1) was undetectable, indicating that Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 exhibited mainly Lewis acidity, which could be due to both the γ-Al2O3 support and Niδ+ species [34]. 3.3 Aqueous-phase hydrogenative ring-rearrangement of FAL The formation of highly dispersed Ni species by DP is critical to the improved dispersion of Ni3P on the support. The DP time may affect the Ni loading and the dispersion of the Ni species [40]. Therefore, the DP time was optimized to achieve both high dispersion and reasonably high loading. As the DP time increased from 4 to 8 h, the content of Ni increased from 12.0% to 14.7 and that of P increased from 2.1% to 2.5% (Table S2). When the DP time was increased to 16 h, the contents of Ni and P increased to 15.0% and 2.6%, respectively. In addition, the specific surface area decreased monotonically with DP time, probably because of partial blockage of the pores by Ni and P species (Table S2) Fig. 6. comparatively shows the variation of FAL conversion and product yield over Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 catalyst prepared with various DP time. Both FAL conversion and CPO yield increased with DP time, in accordance with the Ni and P contents (Table S2). The catalyst with DP time of 16 h performed the highest reactivity, achieving a CPO yield of 74.6% at FAL conversion of 99.9%. Moreover, the yield to THFOL, CPL, and 5-HPO, the over-hydrogenated products, increased with DP time, indicating that Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 prepared by DP for 16 h performed the highest hydrogenation performance. Fig. 7 shows the variation of FAL conversion and product yield as a function of reaction temperature. On increasing the reaction temperature from 140 to 180 °C, FAL conversion and CPO yield increased markedly from 52.3% and 27.3% to 99.9% and 74.6%, respectively. Further increasing the temperature to 200 °C, FAL increased rarely, but CPO yield decreased to 66.3%. The CPO yield increased first and then decreased with the increasing reaction temperature, indicating an optimal reaction temperature was 180 °C. When the temperature was elevated from 180 °C to 200 °C, the yield of CPL increased, suggesting the over-hydrogenation caused by higher temperature. In addition, at 140 °C, the yield of FOL was 23.7%, slightly lower than that of CPO (27.3%). As the temperature was elevated stepwise, the yield of FOL decreased accordingly, but those of hydrogenative ring-rearrangement products (CPO and CPL) increased simultaneously, indicating that the hydrogenative ring-rearrangement was thermodynamically favorable [15,41,42]. To investigate the role of H2 pressure, the reaction was carried out at 180 °C for 60 min at H2 pressure ranging from 1 MPa to 2 MPa and 4 MPa. As seen in Fig. 8 , both FAL conversion and CPO yield increased monotonously with the rising H2 pressure. Moreover, the yield of CPL increased from 0.6% to 9.6%, accompanied by an increase of 5-HPO yield from 4.8% to 11.7%, as the H2 pressure increased from 2 MPa to 4 MPa. The experimental results indicated that the excessive H2 pressure could facilitate the over-hydrogenation of CPO and PED [43,44]. In order to investigate the influence of solvent, water/IPA with various compositions was used to conduct the reaction Fig. 9. demonstrates the influence of solvent composition on the aqueous-phase hydrogenative ring-rearrangement activity of Ni3P/γ-Al2O3. Pure water performed the best activity with a CPO yield of 74.6% at a FAL conversion of 99.9%. By introducing IPA into the solvent mixture (75%water-25%IPA), the FAL conversion and CPO yield decreased to 98.1% and 69.2%, respectively. Decreasing the water composition to 50%, a significant decrease in the CPO yield of 7.5% was observed at FAL conversion of 84.6%, with the main product of FOL (yield of 67.3%). In pure IPA, the CPO did not generate, with the main products of FOL, THFOL, 2-methyl furan (2-MF), and ether. The yield of CPO decreased with the reduced water composition, indicating that water played a crucial role in the hydrogenative ring-rearrangement of FAL. Since the hydrogenative ring-rearrangement and hydrogenolysis of FOL were competitive in the transformation of FAL, the solvent played an important role in tuning the reaction pathway [10,45]. Water was beneficial for the hydrogenative ring-rearrangement to form CPO, while IPA could act as the hydrogen donors to facilitate the transfer hydrogenation to FOL and transfer hydrogenolysis to 2-MF [46–48]. The catalytic performance of Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 catalyst for the aqueous-phase hydrogenative ring-rearrangement of FAL was also compared with the literature report (Table S3). Among the base metal catalysts, the Cu-based catalysts (Cu/ZrO2 and CuZnAl) performed high FAL conversion and CPO yield [43,49]. However, a long reaction time (9 h) was necessary for these catalysts. The CO uptake of Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 was 16.3 μmol·g − 1. The TOF for Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 in hydrogenative ring-rearrangement of FAL was 3.6 × 103 h − 1, calculated at a FAL conversion of 37.4% in 20 min, which was higher than that of Cu/ZrO2 [43]. In short, Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 showed the apparent advantage among the non-noble metal catalysts reported in the literature under comparable conditions, which might be due to the highly-dispersed Ni3P and the Lewis acidic γ-Al2O3 support. For the sake of investigating the kinetics of the FAL hydrogenative ring-rearrangement, the catalytic HDO performance of bi-functional Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 was studied in the temperature range of 160–190 °C with a reaction time of 15–120·min Fig. 10. shows the variation of concentration with reaction time at various temperatures. FAL concentration decreased with temperature and reaction time. With increasing reaction time, the yields of FOL and 2-CPE increased initially and then decreased, indicating that they were the primary intermediates in the reaction. FAL was firstly transformed into FOL, followed by ring-rearrangement to form 2-CPE, which could be further hydrogenated to CPO. Furthermore, the reaction time needed to get the maximum value of the intermediates (FOL and 2-CPE) decreased with the increasing temperature. Taking 2-CPE for example, the needed reaction time decreased from 60 to 20 min, when the reaction temperature was elevated from 160 to 180 °C, accordingly. Fig. 11 a illustrates the variation of − l n ( 1 − x ) against reaction time over bi-functional Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 catalyst at 160–190 °C. A line passing through the origin was obtained at each temperature, indicating that the hydrogenative ring-rearrangement of FAL over Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was first-order with respect to FAL concentration. Hence, the rate constants (k) were equal to the slopes of the lines, which are listed in Table 2 . When ln k was plotted against 1/T, a linear relationship was obtained for Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 catalyst (Fig. 11b). According to the Arrhenius equation, the activation energy (Ea) could be calculated by fitting the slope of the line. The Ea was 64.2 kJ·mol−1 for Ni3P/γ-Al2O3, which was smaller than that for NiFe/SBA-15 (104 kJ·mol−1) and Cu/CuFe2O4@C (139.8 kJ·mol−1) [7,10]. The recyclability of Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 in aqueous-phase hydrogenative ring-rearrangement of FAL is shown in Fig. S5. After three cycles, the conversion of FAL decreased, while the selectivity to CPO stayed unchanged. The XRD patterns of fresh and spent Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 catalysts (Fig. S6) implied that the crystal phase of Ni3P was stable in aqueous-phase hydrogenative ring-rearrangement of FAL. Yang et al. carried out the hydrogenation of FAL in hot water without catalyst, and found n that resinification of furfural was inevitable in hot water, especially in the presence of acids [50]. Thus, the decrease of FAL conversion might be due to the deposition of insoluble resinification compounds. 4 Conclusions In this study, a bifunctional Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was prepared by deposition-precipitation followed by electroless plating and heat treatment. The TEM images revealed that ultrafine Ni3P nanoparticles (∼3.8 nm) were dispersed homogeneously in the Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 catalyst. NH3-TPD curves demonstrated that the weak (0.40 mmol·g − 1) and medium (0.26 mmol·g − 1) acidic sites play the leading role, with strong acidic sites of only 0.06 mmol·g − 1. The Py-FTIR spectra revealed the major surface acid was Lewis acid. The catalytic performance of bi-functional Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 was tested in the aqueous phase. The Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was able to achieve a CPO yield of 74.6% at FAL complete conversion at 180 °C for 1 h. The higher reaction temperature and longer reaction time led to further hydrogenation to generate byproducts like CPL, THFOL and 5-HPO. Water played a crucial role in the hydrogenative ring-rearrangement of FAL to CPO, while isopropanol was helpful to generate FOL and 2-MF. The hydrogenative ring-rearrangement of FAL over Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was first-order with respect to FAL concentration, with the activation energy of 64.2 kJ·mol−1. coredata.dc:description: A bifunctional Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 catalyst with both metal site and Lewis acid site was prepared by an electroless plating method, and applied in hydrogenative ring-rearrangement of furfural to cyclopentanone. The obtained catalyst was characterized by XRD, XPS, XAS, N2 adsorption-desorption, ICP, TEM, CO chemisorption, NH3-TPD and Py-FTIR. The ultrafine Ni3P nanoparticles (∼3.8 nm) were highly dispersed in the catalyst. The exclusive Lewis acidity of Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 was beneficial for the aqueous-phase hydrogenative ring-rearrangement. The effects of DP time, reaction parameters (temperature, H2 pressure, solvent composition, and reaction time) on the catalytic performance were investigated. The yield of cyclopentanone was 74.6% at furfural conversion of 99.9% at 180 °C in 1 h over Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 catalyst using pure water as the solvent. Moreover, the kinetics of hydrogenative ring-rearrangement of furfural catalyzed by Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 was investigated.
coredata.dc:title: Highly selective hydrogenative ring-rearrangement of furfural to cyclopentanone over a bifunctional Ni3P/γ-Al2O3 catalyst
